title: Mumbai To Brace Cloudy Weather Along With Possibility Of Heavy To Very Heavy Rainfall In City Today - Free Press Journal
article_text:
Mumbai: The city of dreams is forecasted to have mostly cloudy weather with a current temperature of 29┬░C. The weather forecast indicates a persistent cloudy atmosphere and precipitation, maintaining a humid atmosphere across the week. Wind conditions are also anticipated to be moderate. Overall, Mumbai's weather shows minimal variation, reflecting a typical tropical climate with regular occurrences of light rain.

Cloudy conditions in Mumbai have persisted since morning, with the Indian Meteorological Department issuing warnings for heavy rains in the city and its suburbs. Gusty winds are expected at speeds of 40-50 kmph, along with potential lightning. The rain intensity is projected to remain high along the Konkan coast, with heavy to very heavy rainfall expected in Mumbai, Thane, Navi Mumbai, Palghar, and Kalyan-Dombivli.

For the week ahead, light rain is expected on Thursday through to the following Wednesday, with similar daily temperatures around 29┬░C during the day and dropping to 27┬░-28┬░C at night.

The Meteorological Department attributes this to a low-pressure area in Madhya Pradesh, resulting in increased wind speed at sea and along the coast. There is a forecast of heavy rains along the entire Konkan coast. Cloudy weather is prevalent in Mumbai, accompanied by warnings of extremely heavy rains in the next 24 hours, prompting alerts for residents.

title: Tamil Nadu rain: Schools to remain closed in 5 districts today after heavy downpours - MSN
article_text:
THOOTHUKUDI: The Tamil Nadu government has declared a holiday for schools in five districts due to heavy rainfall from the intensifying northeast monsoon. Schools will remain closed on Wednesday, November 20, in Ramanathapuram, Thoothukudi, Tirunelveli, Tenkasi, and Tiruvarur districts.
In addition, schools in Kanniyakumari and Pechiparai areas of Kanyakumari district will also remain closed due to continuous rain.
The India Meteorological Department (IMD) has forecasted moderate rainfall across Tamil Nadu for the next five days and issued a rain alert.
Earlier, school holidays were announced in Nagapattinam, Thoothukudi, and Karaikal districts on Tuesday, November 19. While schools in Karaikal were closed, colleges in Thoothukudi remained open.
The heavy rains have caused significant disruptions, particularly in the delta and southern regions. Roads in affected areas are waterlogged, and daily life has been impacted.
The IMD has also predicted thunderstorms and lightning in several parts of the state.
Authorities are on high alert and have deployed disaster management teams to monitor flood-prone areas. Residents are advised to stay cautious and avoid waterlogged areas.
For more news like this visit TOI. Get all the Latest News, City News, India News, Business News, and Sports News. For Entertainment News, TV News, and Lifestyle Tips visit Etimes
India's largest telecom company, Jio, is taking another big step in tech innovation. This time around, the company has introduced JioPC ├в┬А┬Ф a cloud-based virtual desktop service that runs through its set-top box. The idea is simple: turn any TV connected to a Jio set-top box into a full-fledged personal computer. With millions of households across the country owning a TV but not a PC, this could be a pretty big deal. All it takes is a keyboard and mouse plugged into the set-top box, and once your invite is approved, you can access a complete desktop interface right on your television. Since it works through the cloud, it can also power basic AI features in future ├в┬А┬Ф like smart document tools, virtual learning apps, and more. This service is currently in a free trial and available via waitlist.

title: Chennai Weather Update For July 16: IMD Predicts Rainfall In These Regions Of Tamil Nadu - Free Press Journal
article_text:
Chennai: The capital city is known as the Gateway to South India, and usually experiences hot and humid weather conditions during the summer and early monsoon months. The India Meteorological Department (IMD) has predicted a mix of rain and scorching heat across Tamil Nadu over the next few days.

The city's weather is expected to remain warm and humid, with occasional chances of light rainfall due to the ongoing Southwest Monsoon influence. On Wednesday, the capital city woke up at 05: 50 AM and the sun is likely to set at 6: 39 PM. Today, the minimum and maximum temperatures are likely to be around 29 degrees Celsius and 35 degrees Celsius, respectively. The humidity is expected to be around 73 per cent.

Dos & don'ts during Thunderstorm and lightning pic.twitter.com/ofZLI7OTJO

тАФ IMD-Tamilnadu Weather (@ChennaiRmc) June 9, 2025

Today's weather

The Regional Meteorological Department (RMC) has predicted rainfall to continue over Tamil Nadu. Other parts of the state will experience light rainfall and it is likely to be accompanied by thunderstorms. The temperatures are expected to remain above normal, causing discomfort in several regions.

FPJ Shorts
Vanraj Shah Is Back? Ronit Roy To Replace Sudhanshu Pandey In Anupamaa: Reports
US President Donald Trump Signals Tariffs On Drug And Chip Imports By Month-End, Cites National Security Concerns
Bomb Threats To 10 Delhi Schools & One College Over 3 Days Prompt Police Action & Temporary Closures
Mumbai Rains: City's Lakes Over 80% Full As Heavy Showers Boost Water Stock

The city may experience gusty winds. Chennai is likely to experience light to moderate rainfall. Meanwhile, rainfall is also predicted in districts, including Western Ghats, Puducherry, Karaikal, Nilgiris, Tenkasi, Coimbatore, Tiruvenelveli, Theni, Kancheepuram, Chengalpattu, Ariyalur, and Perambalur until the weekend. The skies are expected to be cloudy, and it will remain the same throughout the day.

pic.twitter.com/r6SKlORu8R

тАФ IMD-Tamilnadu Weather (@ChennaiRmc) July 15, 2025

Cyclonic circulation is influencing the rainfall

The rainfall is likely due to a cyclonic circulation over the Southeast Bay of Bengal and the adjoining South Andaman Sea. The weather department also stated that, apart from Tamil Nadu, rainfall is likely to occur in other states, including Odisha, Karnataka, West Bengal, Maharashtra, and Telangana.

Read Also
Bengaluru Weather Forecast: Heavy Rainfall Is Predicted Till July 18; Check Temperatures, Humidity &...

Weather tips

If you're planning to go outdoors, it's advisable to stay hydrated and wear light, breathable clothing. Keeping an umbrella handy could help in case of sudden rain spells. It's also a good idea to avoid outdoor activities during peak afternoon hours when the heat and humidity are at their highest.

title: IMD Weather Live Updates: Heavy Rainfall Alert In Uttar Pradesh, Kerala And Other States; Strong Winds Likely In South India - news24online.com
article_text:
The Indian Meteorological Department (IMD) has forecast widespread rainfall in many parts of the country in the coming week. The department has also issued warnings for heavy to very heavy rains in many states and union territories.
There is a possibility of rain in various areas of Jammu and Kashmir, Himachal Pradesh, Uttarakhand, East-West Uttar Pradesh, Punjab, Haryana and Rajasthan between July 16 and 21. During this, very heavy rains are expected in Jammu and Kashmir and East Rajasthan on July 16, Uttarakhand on July 17, 20 and 21 and East Uttar Pradesh on July 16-17.
Monsoon activities will also remain strong in East and Central India. Heavy rains are likely at isolated places in Madhya Pradesh, Bihar, Jharkhand, Chhattisgarh, Odisha and West Bengal. Very heavy rains may occur especially in Western Madhya Pradesh on July 18 and East Madhya Pradesh on July 16-17.
West India has been warned of torrential rains in the valley areas of Konkan, Goa and Madhya Maharashtra on July 20 and 21, while parts of Gujarat may receive heavy rains on July 16.
Northeast India is expected to continue with light to moderate rainfall throughout the week. At the same time, heavy rains may occur at some places in Assam, Meghalaya, Arunachal Pradesh, Mizoram and Tripura between July 19 and 21.
Kerala, Tamil Nadu, Karnataka, Andhra Pradesh and Telangana are expected to receive heavy to very heavy rainfall till July 21. Strong winds with a speed of 40 to 50 kmph are also likely in this region. Hot and humid weather conditions are likely to prevail over Tamil Nadu, coastal Andhra Pradesh and Rayalaseema on July 16.
Heavy rainfall likely at isolated places over Konkan & Goa on July 16
According to the IMDтАЩs seven-day forecast, Kolkata will see generally cloudy skies with chances of light rain or thunderstorms through the week.
Isolated heavy rainfall likely over Jammu & Kashmir, Himachal Pradesh, Uttarakhand, East Uttar Pradesh on July 16.

title: Tamil Nadu weather update: Heavy rains to lash Coimbatore and Nilgiris; Chennai braces for scorching heat and showers - News9live
article_text:
Chennai: The Chennai Regional Meteorological Centre has warned of heavy rainfall in the hilly regions of Coimbatore and the Nilgiris today, with more intense downpours expected over the next five days. The shift in westerly wind patterns is set to bring moderate rainfall across Tamil Nadu and Puducherry, while isolated areas may experience severe weather conditions.
In addition to the hilly terrains of Coimbatore and the Nilgiris, districts including Theni, Dindigul, Tenkasi, Tiruvannamalai, Cuddalore, and Villupuram, along with Puducherry, are likely to witness heavy rainfall tomorrow. Meanwhile, Chennai is expected to remain cloudy with a possibility of moderate showers. The Met Department has also noted that maximum temperatures across the state will be 2 to 3 degrees Celsius higher than usual.
Scorching Heat and Unpredictable Weather Patterns Continue
Despite the forecast of rain, Tamil Nadu continues to experience soaring temperatures. On the previous day, eight locations recorded temperatures above 100 degrees Fahrenheit, with Madurai Airport registering a scorching 105.8┬░FтАФthe highest in the state. Other areas, including Madurai city, Nagapattinam, Thoothukudi, Vellore, and Puducherry, recorded 101┬░F, while ChennaiтАЩs Nungambakkam, Cuddalore, and Thanjavur touched 100┬░F.
Meteorologists predict that the current weather patternтАФmarked by intense daytime heat followed by evening rainsтАФwill persist for the next week. From the 18th onwards, heavy rainfall is expected in Chennai, Tiruvallur, Chengalpattu, Kanchipuram, Tenkasi, and Theni districts. The Met Department has also cautioned fishermen, warning of strong surface winds reaching speeds of up to 50 kmph.
In Chennai, the skies will remain partly cloudy with chances of light rain in certain areas. The maximum temperature is expected to hover between 38┬░C and 39┬░C, while the minimum will stay around 27┬░C to 28┬░C. Authorities have advised residents to stay alert for sudden weather changes and potential flooding in low-lying regions.

title: Mamata accuses Centre of denying flood relief funds to West Bengal - The Hindu
article_text:
The View From India
									Looking at World Affairs from the Indian perspective.
First Day First Show
									News and reviews from the world of cinema and streaming.
Today's Cache
									Your download of the top 5 technology stories of the day.
Science For All
									The weekly newsletter from science writers takes the jargon out of science and puts the fun in!

									Decoding the headlines with facts, figures, and numbers
Health Matters
									Ramya Kannan writes to you on getting to good health, and staying there
The Hindu On Books
									Books of the week, reviews, excerpts, new titles and features.
Published - July 16, 2025 07:20 am IST - Kolkata
West Bengal Chief Minister Mamata Banerjee. | Photo Credit: The Hindu
West Bengal Chief Minister Mamata Banerjee on Tuesday (July 15, 2025) said that the central government does not offer flood and disaster relief funds for her State but offers help to Assam in times of need. She also alleged that excess water release from the Damodar Valley Corporation (DVC) has led to flooding in many districts in the lower Damodar region, however, DVC has denied all allegations of unplanned water release.
Ms. Banerjee said that even after repeated warnings, the multiple dams of DVC have released heavy loads of water from Jharkhand and flooded West Bengal. She added that as Bengal is a land of water bodies filled with rivers, lakes, and ponds it suffers more during monsoons. She claimed that five lakh ponds have been dug up in the State in recent years to absorb some of the rainwater and reduce the burden on people.
Places like Paschim Medinipur districts Ghatal,┬аparts of Purba Bardhaman┬аdistrict, Khanakul, Arambagh in Hooghly district and Amta, Udaynarayanpur in Howrah district, and other places have been grappling with water logging for the past few weeks.
тАЬBe it DVC, Panchet, Maithon, none of them are listening to us. We have asked the Central government to do desilting work so they can hold an extra 4 lacs metric cusec water and help with this crisis. They have released over 27,000 lacs cubic meters of water between June 18 to July 15,тАЭ Ms. Banerjee said. She also said that they have been fighting this battle with the DVC water release and flooding for over 15 years but to no avail.
However, DVC sources told The Hindu that they release water only after discussions with the committee which includes West Bengal government, Jharkhand government and the DVC authorities along with the Central Water Commission. тАЬThey take view of all the stakeholders and advices about water release and we follow that order only, we do not decide water release amount on our own,тАЭ a top level official at the DVC who wanted remain anonymous said.
The CM also alleged that she has conducted multiple meetings and has urged the central government to find a solution. тАЬPeople are facing huge losses. Assam gets flood relief money; we do not. They only release water here and abandon us... They get votes saying they will work for people, after the votes they only work for themselves,тАЭ Ms. Banerjee added.
She asked all government administrative officials to maintain vigil and constantly monitor the flood situation closely and to create more relief centers than before to help people affected by the floods. The CM asked officials to keep snake bite anti-venom in stock and ensure that no open electric lines cause any electrocution accidents.

title: Weather Update: Monsoon Depression Triggers Heavy Rainfall Alerts in Rajasthan, UP, Bihar, MP, Kerala & More States This Week - Krishi Jagran
article_text:
Monsoon activity is peaking in Northwest India with the depression over North Rajasthan bringing heavy to very heavy showers. (Photo Source: Pexels)

India Meteorological Department (IMD) has issued multiple warnings of intensified monsoon activity across the country, triggered by several active weather systems. Monsoon trough remains active, while two separate low-pressure systems have strengthened, one has intensified into a depression over the central parts of north Rajasthan, and the other persists as a well-marked low-pressure area over north Jharkhand and adjoining south Bihar. As a result, widespread rain, thunderstorms, and isolated heavy to very heavy rainfall are likely to continue over Rajasthan and parts of East and Central India during the next 2тАУ3 days. Here are the detailed regional forecasts.

Northwest India: Widespread Rainfall with Very Heavy Showers in Parts

Monsoon activity is peaking in Northwest India with the depression over North Rajasthan bringing heavy to very heavy showers. Isolated parts of Jammu & Kashmir, Uttarakhand, East Rajasthan, and Uttar Pradesh are on high alert.

The depression over Jharkhand and adjoining Bihar is expected to bring significant rainfall across Eastern and Central India. Meanwhile, another depression formed earlier over West Bengal has moved inland.

Delhi is expected to see cloudy skies, light rain, and cooler-than-normal temperatures over the next four days. Surface wind conditions will vary through the day.

Apart from rainfall, IMD has warned of hot and humid conditions in isolated pockets of Tamil Nadu, Rayalaseema, and Coastal Andhra Pradesh on 16th July.

India is in the grip of an active monsoon phase, driven by multiple low-pressure systems and western disturbances. The coming days are expected to bring widespread rainfall, cooler temperatures in several states, and occasional weather hazards such as thunderstorms, gusty winds, and possible flooding in vulnerable areas. The IMD urges residents, especially in high-alert zones, to stay updated and exercise caution.

title: Weather Update: Heavy Rain Likely In Delhi-NCR Today; Alerts In 25 UP Districts, Flood Havoc In Himachal | Forecast - thedailyjagran.com
article_text:
By Priyanka Koul
Wed, 16 Jul 2025 07:40 AM (IST)
Source:JND
RELATED ARTICLES

Weather Update: Monsoon rains continue to batter North India. Delhi-NCR is preparing for more heavy showers today, with the IMD warning of sudden weather shifts, storms, and intense rainfall. An alert has been issued for several areas in the capital and its surroundings, including Noida and Gurugram. Meanwhile, neighbouring Uttar Pradesh remains on high alert, with warnings in place for 25 districts. The situation is equally grim in Himachal Pradesh, where relentless rains have led to deadly landslides and severe destruction.

Monsoon Grips Delhi, UP, Haryana

The IMD has forecast widespread rainfall in Delhi and the NCR region. тАЬThere is a possibility of rain at many places in Delhi, Noida, Gurugram tomorrow,тАЭ the IMD stated. Alongside the rain, sudden storms and thunderstorms are also expected, which may disrupt daily life and transportation.

In Uttar Pradesh, Light to moderate showers are expected in Lucknow and nearby districts, while heavy rainfall is predicted in several eastern parts of the state. тАЬThere will be heavy rain in a total of about 25 districts including eastern UP,тАЭ said senior meteorologist Atul Kumar Singh. In addition, 34 districts have been placed under alert for thunderstorms accompanied by strong winds and lightning.

Weather Warning for 15th July 2025#imd #WeatherUpdate #mausam #Rainfall #heavyrain #monsoon #rajasthan #jharkhand #odisha #westbengal #jammu #jharkhand #bihar #maharashtra #konkan #kerala #karnataka #chhattisgarh @moesgoi @ndmaindia @DDNational @airnewsalerts pic.twitter.com/KUDPIm47zS

тАФ India Meteorological Department (@Indiametdept) July 15, 2025

The districts likely to be most affected include Sonbhadra, Mirzapur, Chandauli, Varanasi, Bhadohi, Jaunpur, Ghazipur, Azamgarh, Mau, Ballia, Deoria, Gorakhpur, Sant Kabir Nagar, Kushinagar, and Ambedkar Nagar. Western UP is also expected to see тАЬgood rainтАЭ for two consecutive days starting Wednesday.

ALSO READ:┬аDelhi Bomb Scare: Two Top Schools Receive Threatening Email, Evacuated Amid Searches

Rainfall Expected Across Multiple States

The next 24 hours are expected to bring light to moderate rain, with isolated heavy falls across West Bengal, Bihar, Jharkhand, Chhattisgarh, Madhya Pradesh, North Rajasthan, Punjab, Haryana, Konkan, Goa, Coastal Karnataka, and Kerala.

Other regions like Sikkim, Northeast India, Odisha, Jammu and Kashmir, Uttarakhand, Himachal Pradesh, Ladakh, Gujarat, and the Andaman and Nicobar Islands are also likely to experience showers.

ALSO READ:┬аHarry Potter Series: Nick Frost's First Look As Rubeus Hagrid In HBO's Wizarding World Unveiled; Fans React

Himachal Pradesh Faces Deadly Monsoon Toll

Monsoon havoc continues in Himachal Pradesh. There's continuous rainfall since late June which has claimed 106 lives between June 20 and July 15, 2025, according to the State Disaster Management Authority (SDMA). тАЬOf the total deaths, 62 were directly caused by rain-related calamities such as landslides, flash floods, cloudbursts, drowning, electrocution and falls, while 44 persons died in road accidents during the same period,тАЭ the SDMA reported.

The destruction extends beyond human loss. More than 293 pucca and 91 kutcha houses have been completely destroyed, and over 850 hectares of farmland damaged. Public infrastructure worth over тВ╣81 crore, including roads, electricity lines, water supply systems, health centres, and schools, has also been severely impacted.

Rajasthan Reels from Monsoon Disruption

In Rajasthan, life remained disrupted for the second straight day as heavy rain lashed multiple districts. Inundation was reported in Jaipur, Churu, Pali, Bikaner, Sri Ganganagar, and Hanumangarh. Rail services in Jodhpur were affected as water submerged tracks, while road connectivity in Bundi was cut off after the Meja river overflowed.

The IMD recorded the highest rainfall in BhilwaraтАЩs Bijolia, followed by Bhainsrodgarh in Chittorgarh and Makrana in Nagaur. Other heavily affected areas include TonkтАЩs Niwai, KotaтАЩs Mandana, and JaipurтАЩs Sambhar.

Jaipur witnessed severe waterlogging, with water entering homes and creating massive traffic snarls. Vehicles were stranded for hours, particularly on Tonk Road. For Wednesday, heavy to very heavy rain alerts have been issued for Kota, Udaipur, Bharatpur, and Bikaner divisions.

As the monsoon maintains its grip across northern India, authorities urge residents in the affected regions to remain alert, follow weather updates closely, and avoid unnecessary travel. The coming days are expected to test both infrastructure and resilience, as rain continues to batter large swaths of the country.

Coaching Bus Stuck In Jaipur Ditch As Rain Lashes City 18 Dead Red Alert In 28 Districts Issued Today

Rajasthan Monsoon Coaching bus trapped in Jaipur ditch amid rain: Children scream in panic as heavy rainfall kills 18; red alert in 28 districts today

Jaipur 53 minutes ago



Copy link

The Meteorological Department has issued a rain alert for 28 districts of Rajasthan on Wednesday as well.

The continuous rainfall is increasing difficulties across the state.

In the past two days, 18 people have lost their lives due to rain-related incidents.

Heavy rain warning for Baran and Jhalawar

A warning for heavy rainfall has been issued for the Baran and Jhalawar regions.

Meanwhile, in Jaipur, the spell of rain that began late Tuesday night continued into Wednesday morning.

Jaipur Collector Jitendra Soni went out to see the condition of the city on Tuesday. He gave instructions to improve the waterlogged areas as soon as possible

Coaching bus gets stuck in Chaumu

In Jaipur districtтАЩs Chaumu town, a coaching bus filled with children got stuck in a pothole.

The children began screaming in fear.

On Tuesday, heavy rainfall was recorded in many areas of Jaipur, Churu, Bikaner, Sri Ganganagar, and Hanumangarh.

A house collapsed in Dhora Mohalla of Kankroli in Rajsamand. One person died in the accident

Kota and Chittorgarh see most deaths

In the past two days, 18 deaths have been reported across Rajasthan due to various rain-related incidents.

Kota and Chittorgarh districts recorded the highest number with four deaths each.

Pratapgarh reported three deaths, Churu two, and Rajsamand, Bharatpur, Alwar, Pali, and Dholpur reported one death each.

In Kota, two bodies out of six people who were swept away in the Chambal River were recovered on Tuesday.

Due to waterlogging at the Chapatia crematorium in Churu's Sujangarh Bhojlai Bas, a temporary bridge was constructed for the funeral procession

Rainfall to ease from 17 July

According to weather experts, the ongoing spell of heavy rainfall is expected to weaken from 17 July.

It is likely that a "break spell" in the monsoon will occur from 19 July.

During this period, only light showers may be seen in some areas, while most regions are expected to remain dry.

Here is the bar chart showing the Maximum and Minimum Temperatures of major cities in Rajasthan. Blue bars represent maximum temperatures. Orange bars represent minimum temperatures. title: 10,000 stranded as rains lash Raj, IMD sounds red alert - The New Indian Express
article_text:
JAIPUR: Monsoon continues to wreak havoc in Rajasthan, with relentless rainfall severely impacting eastern and southeastern parts of the state. Widespread flooding has submerged colonies, disrupted rail services, and forced closure of multiple national highways. Nearly 10,000 people are reportedly confined to their homes due to waterlogging and blocked roads.
The meteorological department has issued a red alert for heavy rainfall in three districts on Tuesday, along with an orange alert in ten other districts and yellow alert in 20. In view of the worsening situation, government and private schools in Kota and Pali districts will remain closed on July 15.
At least 16 people have died in various rain-related incidents across the state in the past 24 hours. According to official reports, four deaths were reported in Chittorgarh, three in Pratapgarh, two in Churu, four in Kota, and one each in Bharatpur and Pali. The fatalities were caused by drowning, lightning strikes, building collapses, and electrocution.
In a tragic incident on Monday, seven friends who had gone for a picnic in Kota were swept away in the overflowing Chambal River. While one person was rescued, and two friends were found dead, four remain missing. Search and rescue operations are ongoing.
This year, the southwest monsoon has been particularly active in Rajasthan. Over 33 districts have already recorded 60% or more of their average seasonal rainfall in the first spell. Due to the continuous water inflow, six major dams are nearing capacity. On Monday, both the Kota Barrage and Jawahar Sagar Dam overflowed following heavy rains in the Hadauti and Marwar regions. Authorities have opened the gates to release excess water.
In the past 24 hours, highest rainfall was recorded at Bhainsrorgarh in Chittorgarh district with 174 mm, while Bijaulia in Bhilwara, and Duni in Tonk received 172 mm, 146 mm of rainfall, respectively. Authorities have urged residents to stay indoors and remain alert amid heavy rain forecast.
Water release triggers flooding in 3 Bengal dists
Meanwhile, incessant rain in Jharkhand has prompted release of water from DVCтАЩs Panchet and Maithan reservoirs, creating a flood-like situation in at least three districts in West Bengal тАУ Howrah, Hooghly and East Burdwan. Chief Minister Mamata Banerjee has ordered the administration of ten districts to keep a close eye on the situation. Flood-relief protocols have been activated in affected areas and the process of evacuating residents of low-lying areas has begun.

Reportedly, 84 ghats of Varanasi are completely submerged and 18 gates of Matatila Dam in Lalitpur and 8 gates of Govind Sagar Dam have been opened.

Heavy rains continue in the hilly states of Uttarakhand and Himachal Pradesh. According to media reports 200 roads in Himachal and 58 in Uttarakhand have been closed due to landslides. Heavy rain warning has been issued in both the states today.

Rainfall has occurred in more than 25 districts including Gwalior, Bhopal, Indore. Gwalior received the highest rainfall of 2.3 inches.

Due to heavy rains in the state within the week, rivers and streams are overflowing. Even today, there is an alert of very heavy or heavy rain in 18 districts.

Heavy rains have been witnessed in Rajasthan and 18 people have died in incidents relating to this within 2 days.

Areas like Jaipur, Churu, Bikaner, Sriganganagar, Hanumangarh districts are flooded with water up to 4-5 feet and suffer water logging in several areas. The water level of the Mej river in Bundi is above the danger mark. Many villages have lost contact with the headquarters.

IMD Rain Alert: Big news! There will be heavy rains in these states in the next 72 hours, alert issued
- Advertisement -
- Advertisement -

Very Heavy Rain Alert: Heavy to very heavy rains are expected in many parts of the country in the next 48 hours. According to the Meteorological Department, there is a pressure over the central parts of North Rajasthan and a low pressure area over North Jharkhand and adjoining South Bihar. Due to its effect, heavy to very heavy rains are likely in Rajasthan, eastern and adjoining central India during the next 2 to 3 days. The India Meteorological Department has issued an alert for many states.

Very Heavy Rain Alert: Monsoon is active all over India. Due to the activation of the weather system, heavy rains may occur in many parts of the country for the next 72 hours. According to the Meteorological Department, there is a pressure over the central parts of North Rajasthan and a low pressure area over North Jharkhand and adjoining South Bihar. Due to these seasonal activities, heavy to very heavy rains may occur in many parts of the country.

IMD estimates that very heavy rains may occur in Rajasthan, eastern and adjoining central India in the next 3 to 4 days. According to the Meteorological Department, the pressure area in and around Jharkhand has moved in the west-northwest direction, which weakened and turned into a low pressure area.

According to the India Meteorological Department, the low pressure area over the central parts of North Rajasthan is slowly moving in the west-northwest direction. It has turned into a pressure area. Due to seasonal activities, heavy to very heavy rains are expected in many areas including Bihar, Chhattisgarh, coastal Karnataka, Jammu and Kashmir, Jharkhand, Kerala and Mahe, Konkan and Goa, Madhya Maharashtra, Odisha, Rajasthan in the coming days.

According to the Meteorological Department, heavy rains are likely at some places in Jammu and Kashmir, Himachal Pradesh, Uttarakhand, eastern Uttar Pradesh during July 16 to 21. Very heavy rains may occur in Punjab, Haryana, Western Uttar Pradesh, Rajasthan, Jammu and Kashmir, Eastern Rajasthan during July 16, 17 and 21.

Heavy rains may occur over Madhya Pradesh, Chhattisgarh, Bihar, Jharkhand, Andaman and Nicobar Islands, Odisha, Sub-Himalayan West Bengal and Sikkim, Gangetic plains of West Bengal, Western Madhya Pradesh, Eastern Madhya Pradesh, Bihar and Jharkhand during July 16 to 19.

According to the IMD, moderate to heavy rains accompanied with thunderstorms and lightning are likely to continue at many places over Northeast India during the next 7 days. Heavy rains are likely at some places over Assam and Meghalaya, Arunachal Pradesh, Mizoram and Tripura during July 16 and July 19 to 21.

Heavy to very heavy rains are likely at some places over Kerala and Mahe, Tamil Nadu, Coastal and South Interior Karnataka during July 16 to 21. Very heavy rains are likely at some places over North Interior Karnataka on July 16.

title: Heavy rain lashes Dakshina Kannada, Udupi; orange alert for July 16 - Daijiworld
article_text:
Daijiworld Media Network- Mangaluru/ Udupi

Mangaluru/Udupi, Jul 16: The monsoon has regained intensity across the coastal belt, bringing heavy rainfall throughout Tuesday in Dakshina Kannada and Udupi districts. Minor damage was reported in some areas, prompting authorities to declare a holiday in parts of Kadaba, Ullal, and Bantwal taluks.

In Bantwal taluk's Badagabellur, a tree fell on a house, causing damage. Light damage to houses was also reported in Panemangalore, Biliyur, and Arala villages. Near Veerakamba, close to Vittal, a tree fell across the road, briefly disrupting vehicle movement. Mangaluru city witnessed consistent heavy rainfall, resulting in waterlogging in low-lying areas and traffic congestion in several parts.

Heavy rain was also reported in Kadaba, Beltangady, Dharmasthala, Ujire, Madanthyar, Uppinangady, Puttur, Sullia, Subrahmanya, Panja, Kollamogru, Surathkal, Moodbidri, Bajpe, Kateel, Vittal, Bantwal, Kanyana, and Peruvai, among other locations.

Six houses in the district have sustained partial damage. Around 20 electricity poles and one transformer were affected. In response, 15 members of the SDRF/civil defence team have been deployed in Mangaluru, 10 in Subrahmanya, and a 25-member NDRF team is stationed in Puttur. A total of 26 boats have been kept ready.

The India Meteorological Department (IMD) has issued an orange alert for July 16, forecasting heavy rainfall accompanied by strong winds. Alerts have also been announced for July 17 and 18.

Steady rain in Udupi

Udupi district received steady rain from Tuesday morning through the night. As per IMD forecasts, an orange alert is in place for Wednesday and Thursday.

Continuous showers since early morning led to rivers and streams swelling again. While rainfall slightly reduced post noon, it picked up again by evening.

The district administration has warned fishermen not to venture into the sea until July 18, as strong winds ranging from 40 to 50 kmph are expected over the Arabian Sea.

Heavy showers were also recorded in Byndoor, Kundapur, Karkala, Hebri, Padubidri, Kaup, Uchila, Katapady, Udupi, Manipal, Malpe, Brahmavar, and Kota regions.

title: Monsoon Alert: Heavy rain likely in 25 districts of Uttar Pradesh - Times Bull
article_text:
UP Weather Update: Monsoon rains have stopped the pace of life in many areas of Uttar Pradesh, which is creating new trouble for everyone. Waterlogging has occurred due to rain at many places in the state, due to which the passersby are facing problems. Due to late-night rain in some areas of western UP, the temperature level has dropped, where people have got relief from the scorching heat.

Even now, movement of clouds is being seen in eastern areas, including western UP. In some parts, it has rained with thunder in the early morning. According to the Indian Meteorological Department, a heavy rain alert has been issued in more than 25 districts of the state. Bad weather is expected for 48 hours. You can find below what kind of weather will be where.

Read More:┬аInd vs Eng: What will be the playing eleven of Team India in the fourth test match? Know here

Read More:┬аWant to Earn тВ╣20,500 as Interest Every Month? Invest in This Safe Post-Retirement Scheme

Heavy rain in these districts

If the Meteorological Department is to be believed, a period of heavy rain can be seen in more than 25 districts of Uttar Pradesh. According to IMD, a warning of heavy rain with thunderstorms has been issued in Sonbhadra, Mirzapur, Chandauli, Banda, Chitrakoot and Kaushambi. Apart from these, rain with strong winds has also been predicted in Ballia, Prayagraj, Pratapgarh, Varanasi, Santarvi Das Nagar and Jaunpur.

Heavy rain can also become a problem for people in Ghazipur, Azamgarh, Mau and Deoria. The weather can remain bad here for the next two days. Rainfall can break records in Gorakhpur, Sant Kabir Nagar, Kushinagar, Lakhimpur Kheri and Sultanpur. Along with all these, there may be rain in Ambedkar Nagar, Rampur, Bareilly, Pilibhit, Shahjahanpur and Mahoba and surrounding areas.

How will the weather be here?

According to IMD, thundershowers are expected in many areas of western UP. Along with this, an alert has also been issued for thunderstorms and lightning in both areas. From July 17 to July 21, there may be more rain than expected in UP. Heavy rain is expected on July 19.

title: IMD Weather Update: 7-Day Warning For Heavy Rain, Thunderstorms Issued Across Multiple States - MSN
article_text:
As the monsoon extends its influence over India, pouring heavy rain over states such as Uttarakhand, Rajasthan, and Madhya Pradesh, the India Meteorological Department (IMD) has sounded a seven-day warning for rain, thunderstorms, and lightning over various areas. While intense showers are being witnessed in some regions, others such as parts of Delhi, Uttar Pradesh, and Bihar are witnessing irregular and comparatively lighter rains.
As per the latest IMD prediction, scattered heavy rain is expected on:
July 21: Jammu and Kashmir, Himachal Pradesh, Uttarakhand, East Uttar Pradesh, Punjab, Haryana, and West Uttar Pradesh.
In addition, the IMD expects very heavy rain in:
July 17 to July 21: Uttarakhand.
Light to moderate rainfall with thunderstorms and lightning is probable at several places in the Western Himalayan region and the adjacent plains in the next seven days.
Skymet, a private weather forecaster, has the following prediction for today, July 16:
Heavy Rainfall at Isolated Places with Light to Moderate Rain:
People in the affected areas need to keep themselves informed about local weather warnings and take required precautions as the monsoon activity prevails.

title: Telangana, Andhra Pradesh Weather LATEST update: States to brace for heavy monsoon rains? Check - Asianet Newsable
article_text:
HOME
INDIA
TELANGANA, ANDHRA PRADESH WEATHER LATEST UPDATE: STATES TO BRACE FOR HEAVY MONSOON RAINS? CHECK
Telangana, Andhra Pradesh Weather LATEST update: States to brace for heavy monsoon rains? Check
The real monsoon season is starting in Telangana and Andhra Pradesh. Although the monsoon arrived early, the rains lagged behind. Now, it seems that the people of Telangana and AP will witness the true monsoon season
2 Min read
Amrita Ghosh
Published : Jul 16 2025, 08:31 AM IST
FB
TW
Linkdin
Whatsapp
Follow Us
1
6
Image Credit : Getty

Weather Updates: The Meteorological Department has good news for the people of Telugu states waiting for rains. Weather conditions are changing favorably for heavy and very heavy rainfall... It has been reported that heavy rains will occur from now on. The Meteorological Department said that there will be heavy rains in the second half of July due to the active southwest monsoon, low pressure, depressions, and trough effects.

Already, heavy rains are falling in the northern states as well as neighboring states like Maharashtra, Karnataka, and Kerala... but there is no trace of rain in Andhra Pradesh and Telangana. But now rain warnings have been issued for these states as well. Moderate rains have already started and the Meteorological Department has said that these will turn into heavy rains.

2
6
Image Credit : Getty

The Meteorological Department said that there is a possibility of moderate rains in Telangana today (July 16, Wednesday). It said that there is a possibility of scattered showers in Adilabad, Kumram Bheem Asifabad, Nirmal, Jagtial, Nizamabad, Sangareddy, Medak, Kamareddy, Gadwal, Narayanapet, Mahabubnagar, Wanaparthy, Nagar Kurnool, and Vikarabad districts.

The Telugu people will get relief from the increased heat and humidity of the last two or three days. The Hyderabad Meteorological Center has announced that the weather in Hyderabad and its suburbs, Medchal and Rangareddy districts, will change completely... It will be cool and pleasant with light showers.

The Meteorological Department has announced that moderate rains will occur in Andhra Pradesh today (Wednesday). It announced that there is a chance of light rains in Parvathipuram Manyam, Visakhapatnam, Vizianagaram, Alluri Sitaramaraju, NTR, Guntur, Bapatla, Palnadu, Chittoor, Prakasam, Nellore, Tirupati, Anantapur, Sri Sathya Sai, Kurnool, Nandyal, Kadapa, and Annamayya districts.

Image Credit : Getty

Heavy rains are already falling in areas like Visakhapatnam in Andhra Pradesh. The Meteorological Department said that these rains will spread to more districts from tonight... There is a possibility of heavy to very heavy rains on July 17. It warned of heavy to very heavy rains in Rayalaseema and Yanam areas.

6
Image Credit : Getty

Heavy rains will start in Telangana from tomorrow (July 17, Thursday). The Meteorological Department revealed that heavy to very heavy rains will occur especially in Bhupalapally, Mulugu, Warangal, and Mahabubabad districts. It said that heavy rains will also occur in Hyderabad and Rangareddy districts. The Meteorological Department is warning people to be alert as there will be heavy rains with strong winds.

рдЖрдИрдПрдордбреА рдиреЗ рджрд┐рд▓реНрд▓реА-рдПрдирд╕реАрдЖрд░ рдореЗрдВ рд╣рд▓реНрдХреА рд╕реЗ рдордзреНрдпрдо рдмрд╛рд░рд┐рд╢ рдХреЗ рд▓рд┐рдП рдпреЗрд▓реЛ рдЕрд▓рд░реНрдЯ рдЬрд╛рд░реА рдХрд┐рдпрд╛ рд╣реИ. рджрд┐рд▓реНрд▓реА-рдПрдирд╕реАрдЖрд░ рдореЙрдирд╕реВрди рдЬрдордХрд░ рдмрд░рд╕ рд░рд╣рд╛. рдЖрдИрдПрдордбреА рдиреЗ рдЖрдЬ рднреА рджрд┐рд▓реНтАНрд▓реА рдореЗрдВ рдмрд╛рд░рд┐рд╢ рдХреА рдЖрд╢рдВрдХрд╛ рдЬрддрд╛рдИ рд╣реИ. рдореМрд╕рдо рд╡рд┐рднрд╛рдЧ рдХреЗ рдореБрддрд╛рдмрд┐рдХ, рдЕрдЪрд╛рдирдХ рдореМрд╕рдо рдХрд░рд╡рдЯ рд▓реЗ рд╕рдХрддрд╛ рд╣реИ рдФрд░ рдЖрдВрдзреА рдЖрдиреЗ рдХрд╛ рднреА рдкреВрд░реНрд╡рд╛рдиреБрдорд╛рди рд╣реИ. рдореМрд╕рдо рд╡рд┐рднрд╛рдЧ рдХреА рдУрд░ рд╕реЗ рдЬрд╛рд░реА рдЕрдкрдбреЗрдЯ рдХреЗ рдЕрдиреБрд╕рд╛рд░ рдХрд▓ рджрд┐рд▓реНтАНрд▓реА, рдиреЛрдПрдбрд╛, рдЧреБрд░реБрдЧреНрд░рд╛рдо рдореЗрдВ рдХрдИ рд╕реНтАНрдерд╛рдиреЛрдВ рдкрд░ рдмрд╛рд░рд┐рд╢ рдХреЗ рдЖрд╕рд╛рд░ рд╣реИрдВред
рд╡рд╣реАрдВ рджрд┐рд▓реНрд▓реА рдореЗрдВ рдордВрдЧрд▓рд╡рд╛рд░ рдХреЛ рдХрд░реАрдм рджреЛ рд╕рд╛рд▓ рдмрд╛рдж рд╕рдмрд╕реЗ рд╕рд╛рдл рд╣рд╡рд╛ рдХрд╛ рдЕрдиреБрднрд╡ рд╣реБрдЖ. рд▓рдЧрд╛рддрд╛рд░ рдмрд╛рд░рд┐рд╢ рдФрд░ рдЕрдиреБрдХреВрд▓ рд╣рд╡рд╛ рдХреА рд╕реНрдерд┐рддрд┐ рдиреЗ рд╢рд╣рд░ рдХреА рд╡рд╛рдпреБ рдЧреБрдгрд╡рддреНрддрд╛ рдХреЛ рдХрдИ рдШрдВрдЯреЛрдВ рддрдХ 'рдЕрдЪреНрдЫреА' рд╢реНрд░реЗрдгреА рдореЗрдВ рдкрд╣реБрдВрдЪрд╛ рджрд┐рдпрд╛. рдХреЗрдВрджреНрд░реАрдп рдкреНрд░рджреВрд╖рдг рдирд┐рдпрдВрддреНрд░рдг рдмреЛрд░реНрдб (CPCB) рдХреЗ рдЕрдиреБрд╕рд╛рд░, 24 рдШрдВрдЯреЗ рдХрд╛ рдФрд╕рдд рд╡рд╛рдпреБ рдЧреБрдгрд╡рддреНрддрд╛ рд╕реВрдЪрдХрд╛рдВрдХ (AQI) рд╢рд╛рдо 4 рдмрдЬреЗ 51 рдкрд░ рдкрд╣реБрдВрдЪ рдЧрдпрд╛ - рдЬреЛ 'рд╕рдВрддреЛрд╖рдЬрдирдХ' рд╢реНрд░реЗрдгреА рдореЗрдВ рд╣реИ. рдЗрд╕рд╕реЗ рдкрд╣рд▓реЗ, рд╢рд╣рд░ рдХрд╛ AQI 48 рдФрд░ 50 рдХреЗ рдмреАрдЪ рд░рд╣рд╛, рдЬреЛ рджреЛрдкрд╣рд░ рддрдХ рд▓рдЧрд╛рддрд╛рд░ 'рдЕрдЪреНрдЫреА' рд╢реНрд░реЗрдгреА рдореЗрдВ рдмрдирд╛ рд░рд╣рд╛ред рдпрд╣ 10 рд╕рд┐рддрдВрдмрд░, 2023 рдХреЗ рдмрд╛рдж рд╕реЗ рджрд┐рд▓реНрд▓реА рдореЗрдВ рджреЗрдЦреА рдЧрдИ рд╕рдмрд╕реЗ рд╕рд╛рдл рд╣рд╡рд╛ рдереА, рдЬрдм AQI 45 рджрд░реНрдЬ рдХрд┐рдпрд╛ рдЧрдпрд╛ рдерд╛.
рдЬреБрд▓рд╛рдИ рдореЗрдВ рдЕрдм рддрдХ, рджрд┐рд▓реНрд▓реА рдореЗрдВ 98.4 рдорд┐рдореА рдмрд╛рд░рд┐рд╢ рд╣реБрдИ рд╣реИ, рдЬреЛ рдорд╛рд╕рд┐рдХ рдФрд╕рдд 209.7 рдорд┐рдореА рд╕реЗ рдХрд╛рдлреА рдХрдо рд╣реИ. рдлрд┐рд░ рднреА, рдЖрдИрдПрдордбреА рдиреЗ рднрд╡рд┐рд╖реНрдпрд╡рд╛рдгреА рдХреА рд╣реИ рдХрд┐ рдЕрдЧрд▓реЗ рдХреБрдЫ рджрд┐рдиреЛрдВ рдореЗрдВ рд╣рд▓реНрдХреА рд╕реЗ рдордзреНрдпрдо рдмрд╛рд░рд┐рд╢ рдЬрд╛рд░реА рд░рд╣реЗрдЧреА, рдЬрд┐рд╕рд╕реЗ рд╣рд╡рд╛ рдХреЗ рд╕реНрд╡рдЪреНрдЫ рд╣реЛрдиреЗ рдХреА рд╕рдВрднрд╛рд╡рдирд╛ рд╣реИ. рдЕрдиреБрдорд╛рди рд╣реИ рдХрд┐ рджрд┐рд▓реНрд▓реА рдХреА рд╡рд╛рдпреБ рдЧреБрдгрд╡рддреНрддрд╛ рдХрдо рд╕реЗ рдХрдо 18 рдЬреБрд▓рд╛рдИ рддрдХ 'рд╕рдВрддреЛрд╖рдЬрдирдХ' рд╢реНрд░реЗрдгреА рдореЗрдВ рд░рд╣реЗрдЧреА, рдФрд░ рд╕рдВрднрд╡рддрдГ рдЕрдЧрд▓реЗ рджрд┐рдиреЛрдВ рдореЗрдВ 'рдордзреНрдпрдо' рддрдХ рдЧрд┐рд░ рд╕рдХрддреА рд╣реИ.
рдЭрд╛рд░рдЦрдВрдб рдореЗрдВ ┬а17 рдЬреБрд▓рд╛рдИ рддрдХ рднрд╛рд░реА рдмрд╛рд░рд┐рд╢ рд╣реЛрдиреЗ рдХреА рд╕рдВрднрд╛рд╡рдирд╛ рд╣реИ. рднрд╛рд░реА рдмрд╛рд░рд┐рд╢ рдХреЗ рдЪрд▓рддреЗ рд░рд╛рдЬреНрдп рдореЗрдВ рд╕реНтАНрдХреВрд▓ рдмрдВрдж рдХрд░ рджрд┐рдП рдЧрдП рд╣реИрдВ. рдЬрдорд╢реЗрджрдкреБрд░ рдХреЗ рдбрд┐рд╕реНрдЯреНрд░рд┐рдХреНтАНрдЯ рдХрдорд┐рд╢реНтАНрдирд░ рдХрд░реНрдг рд╕рддреНрдпрд╛рд░реНрдереА рджреНрд╡рд╛рд░рд╛ рдЬрд╛рд░реА рдПрдХ рдЖрджреЗрд╢ рдХреЗ рдЕрдиреБрд╕рд╛рд░, рд╕реНрдХреВрд▓ рдЕрдзрд┐рдХрд╛рд░рд┐рдпреЛрдВ рдХреЛ рдкрдврд╝рд╛рдИ рдореЗрдВ рдХрд┐рд╕реА рднреА рддрд░рд╣ рдХреА рдмрд╛рдзрд╛ рдХреЛ рд░реЛрдХрдиреЗ рдХреЗ рд▓рд┐рдП рдСрдирд▓рд╛рдЗрди рдХреНтАНрд▓рд╛рд╕реЗрдЬ рдХрд╛ рдЖрджреЗрд╢ рджрд┐рдпрд╛ рд╣реИ. рд╕рд░рд╛рдпрдХреЗрд▓рд╛-рдЦрд░рд╕рд╛рд╡рд╛рдВ, рдкреВрд░реНрд╡реА рд╕рд┐рдВрд╣рднреВрдо рдФрд░ рдкрд╢реНрдЪрд┐рдореА рд╕рд┐рдВрд╣рднреВрдо рдЬрд┐рд▓реЛрдВ рдореЗрдВ рдЕрддреНрдпрдзрд┐рдХ рднрд╛рд░реА рдмрд╛рд░рд┐рд╢ рд╣реЛрдиреЗ рдХреА рд╕рдВрднрд╛рд╡рдирд╛ рд╣реИ. рдореМрд╕рдо рд╡рд┐рднрд╛рдЧ рдиреЗ рдЧреБрдорд▓рд╛, рдЦреВрдВрдЯреА рдФрд░ рд╕рд┐рдордбреЗрдЧрд╛ рдЬрд┐рд▓реЛрдВ рдХреЗ рд▓рд┐рдП рдСрд░реЗрдВрдЬ рдЕрд▓рд░реНрдЯ рдЬрд╛рд░реА рдХрд┐рдпрд╛ рд╣реИ.
рдЗрд╕ рдмреАрдЪ, рдЖрдИрдПрдордбреА рдиреЗ рд╣рд┐рдорд╛рдЪрд▓ рдкреНрд░рджреЗрд╢ рдХреЗ рд▓рд┐рдП рдСрд░реЗрдВрдЬ рдЕрд▓рд░реНрдЯ рдЬрд╛рд░реА рдХрд┐рдпрд╛ рд╣реИ рдХреНрдпреЛрдВрдХрд┐ рдмрд╛рд░рд┐рд╢ рдЬрд╛рд░реА рд╣реИ. рд░рд╛рдЬреНрдп рдЖрдкрджрд╛ рдкреНрд░рдмрдВрдзрди рдкреНрд░рд╛рдзрд┐рдХрд░рдг (рдПрд╕рдбреАрдПрдордП) рдХреЗ рдЕрдиреБрд╕рд╛рд░, 20 рдЬреВрди рд╕реЗ 14 рдЬреБрд▓рд╛рдИ, 2025 рдХреЗ рдмреАрдЪ рдХреБрд▓ 105 рд▓реЛрдЧреЛрдВ рдХреА рдЬрд╛рди рдЪрд▓реА рдЧрдИ. рд░рд╛рдЬрд╕реНрд╡ рд╡рд┐рднрд╛рдЧ рдХреЗ рдЕрдВрддрд░реНрдЧрдд рд░рд╛рдЬреНрдп рдЖрдкрд╛рддрдХрд╛рд▓реАрди рд╕рдВрдЪрд╛рд▓рди рдХреЗрдВрджреНрд░ (рдПрд╕рдИрдУрд╕реА) рджреНрд╡рд╛рд░рд╛ рдЬрд╛рд░реА рдЖрдзрд┐рдХрд╛рд░рд┐рдХ рд╕рдВрдЪрдпреА рд░рд┐рдкреЛрд░реНрдЯ рдХреЗ рдЕрдиреБрд╕рд╛рд░, 105 рдореМрддреЛрдВ рдореЗрдВ рд╕реЗ 61 рдореМрддреЗрдВ рд╕реАрдзреЗ рддреМрд░ рдкрд░ рдмрд╛рд░рд┐рд╢ рд╕реЗ рд╕рдВрдмрдВрдзрд┐рдд рдЖрдкрджрд╛рдУрдВ рдХреЗ рдХрд╛рд░рдг рд╣реБрдИрдВ, рдЬрд┐рдирдореЗрдВ рднреВрд╕реНрдЦрд▓рди, рдЕрдЪрд╛рдирдХ рдмрд╛рдврд╝, рдмрд╛рджрд▓ рдлрдЯрдирд╛, рдбреВрдмрдирд╛, рдЖрдЧ рд▓рдЧрдиреЗ рдХреА рдШрдЯрдирд╛рдПрдВ рдФрд░ рдмрд┐рдЬрд▓реА рдХрд╛ рдЭрдЯрдХрд╛ рд╢рд╛рдорд┐рд▓ рд╣реИрдВ. рдЗрд╕рдХреЗ рдЕрд▓рд╛рд╡рд╛, рд╕рдбрд╝рдХ рджреБрд░реНрдШрдЯрдирд╛рдУрдВ рдореЗрдВ 44 рд▓реЛрдЧреЛрдВ рдХреА рдЬрд╛рди рдЪрд▓реА рдЧрдИ, рдЬрд┐рдирдХреА рд╕рдВрдЦреНрдпрд╛ рдлрд┐рд╕рд▓рди рднрд░реЗ рдЗрд▓рд╛рдХреЛрдВ, рдХрдо рджреГрд╢реНрдпрддрд╛ рдФрд░ рд▓рдЧрд╛рддрд╛рд░ рдмрд╛рд░рд┐рд╢ рдХреЗ рдХрд╛рд░рдг рд╕рдбрд╝рдХреЛрдВ рдХреЛ рд╣реБрдП рдиреБрдХрд╕рд╛рди рдХреЗ рдХрд╛рд░рдг рддреЗрдЬрд╝реА рд╕реЗ рдмрдврд╝реА рд╣реИ.
рдЖрдИрдПрдордбреА рдиреЗ рдмреБрдзрд╡рд╛рд░ рдХреЗ рд▓рд┐рдП рд╢реНрд░реАрдирдЧрд░ рдореЗрдВ рдмрд╛рд░рд┐рд╢ рдХрд╛ рдпреЗрд▓реЛ рдЕрд▓рд░реНрдЯ рдЬрд╛рд░реА рдХрд┐рдпрд╛ рд╣реИ, рдЬрд┐рд╕рдореЗрдВ 'рдмрд┐рдЬрд▓реА рдХреЗ рд╕рд╛рде рдЧрд░рдЬ рдХреЗ рд╕рд╛рде рдЫреАрдВрдЯреЗ рдкрдбрд╝рдиреЗ' рдХреА рдЪреЗрддрд╛рд╡рдиреА рджреА рдЧрдИ рд╣реИ. рдЖрдИрдПрдордбреА рдХреЗ рдЕрдиреБрд╕рд╛рд░ рдмреБрдзрд╡рд╛рд░ рдХреЛ рдмрд╛рджрд▓ рдЫрд╛рдП рд░рд╣реЗрдВрдЧреЗ рдФрд░ рдмрд╛рд░рд┐рд╢, рдЧрд░рдЬ рдХреЗ рд╕рд╛рде рдЫреАрдВрдЯреЗ рдпрд╛ рдзреВрд▓ рднрд░реА рдЖрдВрдзреА рдХреА рд╕рдВрднрд╛рд╡рдирд╛ рд╣реИ. рджреЛрдиреЛрдВ рджрд┐рдиреЛрдВ рдХрд╛ рддрд╛рдкрдорд╛рди 30 рдбрд┐рдЧреНрд░реА рдФрд░ рдЖрд░реНрджреНрд░рддрд╛ 18 рдбрд┐рдЧреНрд░реА рд░рд╣реЗрдЧреА.

title: Jharkhand Weather Forecast: Heavy Rain To Lash Dhanbad, Jamtara And Other Districts; IMD Issues Alerts - thedailyjagran.com
article_text:
By Nidhi Giri
Wed, 16 Jul 2025 10:44 AM (IST)
Source:JND
RELATED ARTICLES

Jharkhand Weather Update: The Meteorological Center, Ranchi, has issued rain warning in most parts of Jharkhand including Dhanbad till July 17 as monsoon showers continue. Due to low pressure in the Bay of Bengal, it rained intermittently throughout Tuesday. A record rainfall of 605.2 mm has been registered so far in the monsoon season.

The weather body has issued a yellow alert for Dhanbad. Heavy rain is likely in areas of the north-eastern parts. There is also a possibility of thunderstorms and lightning during this period.

ALSO READ:┬аChennai Power Cut On July 16: TANGEDCO Announces Shutdown On Wednesday; Check List Of Areas

Due to the increased rain activity, a drop in temperature has also been recorded. As the rain continues, there is no possibility of any major change in the temperature in the next two days. Following that, there may be a gradual increase.

Heavy Rain Expected In Jamtara

During the next few days, a change in weather pattern will be seen in Jamtara and surrounding areas. There is a possibility of moderate to heavy rain in Jamtara and surrounding areas during the next five days. Due to the change in weather, temperature fluctuations are also likely.

ALSO READ:┬аPatna Metro To 1 Crore Jobs: Nitish Kumar's Cabinet Makes Big Promises Ahead Of Bihar Polls | See List

The difference between the maximum and minimum temperatures will be recorded between three and four degrees Celsius. The wind is expected to blow at a speed of 12 to 19 km per hour.

title: Ranchi Weather Update: IMD Issues Red Alert In These Parts Of Jharkhand; Check More Details - MSN
article_text:
Ranchi: Jharkhand has received relief from the extreme heat. The India Meteorological Department (IMD) has issued a red alert in some areas for Thursday, June 19, 2025. According to the meteorologist, this year, the southwest monsoon has entered Jharkhand via Santhal Pargana from June 17. It has been raining intermittently in Ranchi and the surrounding districts since early Wednesday morning.
According to the IMD, the minimum and maximum temperatures in the city are likely to be around 22 degrees Celsius and 23 degrees Celsius, respectively. The humidity is likely to be around 97 per cent, and the gusty wind is likely to blow at a speed of 21 km/h. The rainfall is likely to be accompanied by lightning, thunderstorms, and squalls. The skies are expected to be cloudy and it will remain the same throughout the day.
The weather department has issued a red alert for Jharkhand due to the expected heavy rainfall. This means the state should prepare for intense and potentially disruptive weather conditions. The IMD has issued a red alert for extremely heavy rainfall in numerous parts of the state. The rainfall is likely in Deoghar, Dumka, Pakur, Jamtara, Giridih, Dhanbad, Godda, Sahibganj, as well as the adjoining central parts, including Ranchi, Hazaribagh, Ramgarh, Gumla, Khunti, and Bokaro.
A yellow alert has been issued for heavy rainfall in some parts of the southern part of East and West Singhbhum, Simdega, Saraikela Kharsawan, and the northwestern part of Palamu, Garhwa, Chatra, Koderma, Latehar, and Lohardaga.
Chennai Weather Update: Heavy Rainfall Is Predicted In Some Parts Of Tamil Nadu; Check Out Details
The weather department has urged people to stay away from low-lying areas, avoid non-essential travel, and exercise caution on waterlogged roads. Farmers are advised to take precautions to protect their crops and farm assets from potential damage due to heavy winds and rain.
Beginning of dialog window. Escape will cancel and close the window.
After a brief dry spell, monsoon showers have returned to Pune, with several parts of the city experiencing heavy downpour since Monday night.
The India Meteorological Department (IMD) issued an Orange alert for continued rain in the city and surrounding areas over the next few hours.
Amid rainfall in Pune, the IMD has warned of heavy showers accompanied by thunderstorms and gusty winds in parts of the state, including nearby regions like Mumbai and Raigad.
In response to the situation, Mumbai Police have urged citizens on social media to avoid visiting the seafront.
Local authorities have also advised citizens to remain cautious, especially during peak traffic hours, as isolated waterlogging and reduced visibility could affect movement.
Meanwhile, other districts in Maharashtra тАФ including Raigad, Kolhapur, and Ratnagiri тАФ are witnessing intense rainfall, with rising river levels and flood alerts issued in some areas.
In Raigad, continuous heavy rain since last night in the Mahabaleshwar region has increased the flow into the Savitri and Gandhari rivers, prompting flood warnings.
Authorities have said tidal waves between 4тАУ5 meters are expected around 2:30 pm today, which may raise water levels in the Savitri River across coastal areas.
District administration in Mahad, Poladpur, Mangaon, and Goregaon has been directed to remain on high alert. Rescue teams have also been asked to stay prepared.

title: Heavy rains forecast across Gangetic Bengal as deep depression moves inland - The Statesman
article_text:
A deep depression over southeastern Gangetic West Bengal and adjoining Bangladesh is expected to bring widespread rainfall across the region on Tuesday, with heavy showers likely in 11 districts, according to the Indian Meteorological Department (IMD).

The system, currently situated about 90 km north of Kolkata and 50 km east of Bardhaman, is likely to move northwestwards and enter Jharkhand within the next 24 hours. As a result, the intensity of rainfall over southern West Bengal is expected to ease from Wednesday. On Tuesday, scattered light to moderate rainfall is expected across all districts of South Bengal, accompanied by thunderstorms and wind speeds ranging between 30-40 km/h. Districts including Purulia, Bankura, East and West Bardhaman, Birbhum, and Murshidabad are likely to witness heavy rain and gusty winds.

Advertisement

Kolkata is forecast to remain overcast throughout the day, with intermittent showers keeping daytime temperatures below normal. High humidity levels may cause discomfort in the absence of rainfall. In North Bengal, heavy rainfall is expected in Darjeeling, Jalpaiguri, Kalimpong, Alipurduar, and Cooch Behar on Tuesday. The wet spell is likely to continue through the weekend, with particularly intense showers forecast for Darjeeling, Kalimpong, and Jalpaiguri on Saturday, and Jalpaiguri and Alipurduar on Sunday.

Advertisement

Other northern districts are likely to receive scattered rain throughout the week. The IMD has warned of rough sea conditions near the coasts of West Bengal, Odisha, and Bangladesh. Fishermen have been advised not to venture into the sea on Tuesday morning. Authorities have also cautioned about potential damage to crops and waterlogging in low-lying areas. Visibility may reduce during heavy downpours, possibly disrupting traffic and leading to congestion in urban centers.

title: Monsoon Session likely to be тАШstormyтАЩ as Congress set to corner government - The New Indian Express
article_text:
NEW DELHI: The upcoming Monsoon session is all set to begin on a stormy note as the main opposition party Congress has decided to question the Government on alleged security lapse in Pahalgam, ceasefire during Operation Sindoor, special intensive revision (SIR) of the electoral rolls in Bihar and crime against women.
This decision was taken in the Congress Parliamentary Party (CPP) strategy meeting held on Tuesday evening.
The meeting was presided over by CPP chairperson Sonia Gandhi with the Congress President Mallikarjun Kharge and Leader of Opposition in the Lok Sabha Rahul Gandhi in attendance.
After the meeting, Deputy Leader in Rajya Sabha Pramod Tiwari said that another meeting of the Indian National Developmental Inclusive Alliance (INDIA) bloc partners would be held before the Session to coordinate strategies and raise issues collectively in both Houses of Parliament.
Tiwari said that about three months have passed since the Pahalgam terror attack in which 26 people were killed but no one has been traced yet.
тАЬAn unprecedented attack had taken place in Pahalgam. We have been seeking a special session to have a discussion on this. We and the people of this country want to know where those terrorists are.┬а Why has no action been taken yet? Who was responsible for the killing of 26 people? Why was no single security personnel present there? Why was the quick response team missing?...Why is Prime Minister Narendra Modi maintaining a mysterious silence on the US president Donald Trump on brokering a ceasefire during Operation Sindoor? He hasnтАЩt responded yet to his claim,тАЭ said Tiwari.
The month-long Monsoon session of Parliament is set to begin on July 21.
He further stated that the Congress would also corner the Government on the issue of тАШelectoral manipulationsтАЩ in elections in states such as Maharashtra, Haryana, and now in Bihar.
The Congress will also raise the issue of rising incidents of crimes against women and Scheduled Castes across the country, particularly in states such as Bihar, Uttar Pradesh, and Odisha.
тАЬThe Congress will raise the demand for the restoration of full statehood to Jammu and Kashmir, which has remained pending despite repeated assurances from the Government,тАЭ he said.
On the question of the impeachment motion against Allahabad High Court justice Yashwant Verma, who is facing allegations of corruption charges after the discovery of burnt cash from his official residence in Delhi, the Congress leader didnтАЩt give any clear reply. He said that several other issues were also discussed in the meeting.
Earlier in the day, the Congress president, Mallikarjun Kharge, met Vice President Jagdeep Dhankhar and said the opposition wants a productive session.
тАЬThe Opposition wants a productive Rajya Sabha session from July 21st. For that to happen a number of strategic, political, foreign policy and socio-economic issues that are of great public concern need to be debated and discussed. Today, I called on the Hon'ble Chairman of the Rajya Sabha and had a fruitful conversation,тАЭ Kharge wrote on тАШXтАЩ.
The Opposition wants a productive Rajya Sabha session from July 21st. For that to happen a number of strategic, political, foreign policy and socio-economic issues that are of great public concern need to be debated and discussed. Today, I called on the Hon'ble Chairman of theтАж pic.twitter.com/FG529olfUC

title: Heavy rains continue across MP, 18.2 inches recorded so far: Niwari sees 103% rainfall; orange, yellow aler... - Bhaskar English
article_text:
English News

Local

Mp

Heavy Rains Continue Across MP, 18.2 Inches Recorded So Far: Niwari Sees 103% Rainfall; Orange, Yellow Alert In 18 Districts Today

Heavy rain continue across MP, 18.2 inches recorded so far: Niwari sees 103% rainfall; orange, yellow alert in 18 districts today

Bhopal 4 hours ago



Copy link

Water was released from the dams of Shivpuri on Tuesday as well.

The spell of heavy rain continued across Madhya Pradesh on Tuesday, affecting more than 25 districts including Gwalior, Bhopal, and Indore.

Gwalior recorded the highest rainfall of 2.3 inches in just nine hours. Khargone received 1.5 inches, Sidhi 1 inch, and Umaria more than half an inch of rain. Heavy rain was also reported in Shajapur and Raisen.

Light showers were observed in Bhopal, Datia, Indore, Narmadapuram, Sheopur, Shivpuri, Mandla, Sagar, Seoni, Balaghat, Rajgarh, Sehore, Agar-Malwa, and Dewas. Despite the widespread rainfall, no casualties or rain-related incidents were reported in the past 24 hours.

Rivers and streams overflow, more rain ahead

Due to intense rains over the past week, rivers and streams across many regions are in spate. Although the situation remained relatively calm on Tuesday, weather officials have warned of another strong system forming from Wednesday.

An alert for very heavy or heavy rainfall has been issued in 18 districts starting today, as the rain pattern is expected to intensify again.

Visuals of heavy rain from different districts..

Seasonal rainfall surpasses average so far

MP has received an average of 18.2 inches of rainfall this monsoonтАФnearly half of the season's quota. This is 72% or 5.6 inches above the normal average of 10.6 inches by this time of the season.

Niwari district has already received 103% of its seasonal average, with 31.46 inches of rain against a normal of 30.5 inches. In contrast, districts in the Indore and Ujjain divisions are trailing behind significantly.

Weather in major cities and divisions

Among the five major cities, Jabalpur has recorded the highest rainfall at 21.6 inches, followed by Gwalior at 18.5 inches, Bhopal at 14.5 inches, Ujjain at 8 inches, and Indore at just 7 inches.

Tikamgarh recorded 91% rainfall with 33 inches, Chhatarpur 75% with 28 inches, Shivpuri 82% with 25.3 inches, and Mandla 75% with 35 inches.

Rainfall has been significantly better in eastern Madhya Pradesh, particularly in divisions like Jabalpur, Rewa, Shahdol, and Sagar, which have received 86% more rainfall than the average.

On the other hand, western divisions тАФ Bhopal, Indore, Ujjain, Gwalior, Chambal, and NarmadapuramтАФhave received 57% above average rainfall. Still, many districts in Indore and Ujjain divisions remain dry. Of the 15 districts in these regions, 10 have not yet recorded even 10 inches of rain.

Weather department issues fresh warning

According to meteorologist Arun Sharma, a monsoon trough is currently passing through the upper region of the state.

With a low-pressure area developing nearby, the state is likely to experience another spell of heavy rainfall starting Wednesday. A rain alert has been issued for the next four days.

title: "A central team will soon visit Himachal to study cloudburst and damage caused from flash floods: CM Sukhu - The News Mill
article_text:
тАЬA central team will soon visit Himachal to study cloudburst and damage caused from flash floods: CM Sukhu

Written By: ANI

| Published on: Jul 16, 2025

ANI Photo | тАЬA central team will soon visit Himachal to study cloudburst and damage caused from flash floods: CM Sukhu

Himachal Pradesh Chief Minister Sukhvinder Singh Sukhu said that a central team would soon visit the state to study the cloudburst and the damage caused by the flash floods in the state.
CM Sukhu met Union Home Minister Amit Shah in New Delhi on Tuesday and apprised him that the state had suffered damages amounting to around Rs 1000 crore, even as the monsoon had just begun.
Speaking to the media, the CM said, тАЬA discussion was held with the Home Minister regarding the disaster that struck Himachal Pradesh. The disaster has caused significant damage. The Home Minister stated that he will personally visit Himachal Pradesh in the coming days. He has instructed the concerned official that there is a need to study the cloudburst incidents. A central team will soon visit Himachal Pradesh to study the cloudburst and the damage caused by the disaster. I have also raised the issue of a special relief package, and the Home Minister said that it would be considered after the central team visit.тАЭ
During the meeting, CM Sukhu informed Home Minister Shah that precious lives had been lost and key infrastructure, including roads, bridges, buildings, irrigation schemes, water supply schemes and electricity supply systems, had been severely affected during this disaster.
The Chief Minister requested support from the Central Government for relief and restoration works.
He further said that natural disasters had become a recurring phenomenon since 2023 and the state had incurred cumulative losses of approximately Rs 21,000 crore over the last three years, as per the release.
He added that the state government was making every effort to provide relief to the affected people through the State Disaster Response Fund (SDRF) and the National Disaster Response Fund (NDRF). However, due to the repeated occurrence of such disasters, it had become increasingly difficult for the state to undertake restoration works and rebuild infrastructure with its limited resources.
CM Sukhu also held a discussion with Union Minister Nitin Gadkari regarding the NH road projects.
CM Sukhu said, тАЬWe had a discussion with Union Minister Nitin Gadkari regarding the National Highway and NHAI. We have asked the minister that, as a disaster has hit the state, we should get funds under the Central Road Fund (CRF). The minister has said that he will consider all the issues.тАЭ (ANI)

title: Bihar Weather Alert: IMD Warns of Severe Rain, Lightning Threat in 38 Districts - KKNLive.com
article_text:
The India Meteorological Department (IMD) has issued a heavy rainfall alert across Bihar, warning of intense showers and lightning strikes in 38 districts. The state is bracing for widespread monsoon-related disruptions, with several rivers showing rising water levels. Patna, Gaya, Purnia, and other key cities are expected to be hit hard.

Monsoon Turns Fierce in Bihar

Monsoon rains, once welcomed as relief, have now turned threatening. After moderate rainfall on July 15, the situation is worsening. On Wednesday, Bihar is likely to face severe to very severe rain. The intensity will be the highest so far this season. IMD forecasts point to dangerous weather conditions, including thunderstorm activity across the state.

This is the first time this monsoon that Bihar will see intense, continuous rainfall. Such a heavy downpour increases the risk of urban flooding, lightning injuries, and agriculture damage.

People Urged to Stay Indoors

Authorities have urged residents to stay indoors. Those living near riverbanks or in flood-prone areas should remain on high alert. Lightning poses a serious risk, especially in open fields and farmlands. People are advised to shut windows and doors and avoid unnecessary travel. Stepping out during such conditions may risk lives.

Cities Likely to See Rainfall and Thunder

The following temperature and AQI levels were recorded across major cities:

City Max/Min Temperature (┬░C) AQI Patna 31.8 / 25.4 67 Muzaffarpur 31.0 / 24.1 48 Bhagalpur 28.3 / 25.2 42 Gaya 27.9 / 24.6 45 Purnia 30.2 / 25.7 38

These figures reflect data available up to Tuesday. Air quality remains moderately good due to the rain.

District-Wise Rain Forecast in Bihar

According to IMD, the following districts are under a heavy rainfall warning:

Very Heavy Rainfall: Rohtas and Kaimur.

Heavy Rainfall: Buxar, Aurangabad, Arwal, Jehanabad, Nalanda, Sheikhpura, Lakhisarai, Jamui, and Banka.

Rainfall Expected: Patna, Gaya, Purnia, West Champaran, East Champaran, Gopalganj, Siwan, and Saran.

In total, all 38 districts in Bihar are likely to receive rainfall on Wednesday.

Orange Alert for Lightning

There is a high probability of lightning strikes in:

Bhojpur

Buxar

Kaimur

Rohtas

Aurangabad

Arwal

Due to this, the IMD has issued an Orange Alert. Residents, especially farmers, are being warned not to work in open fields. If the weather worsens, they should immediately seek shelter in permanent structures.

Rivers Rising Across Bihar

Heavy rainfall across Bihar and neighboring states is causing rivers to swell. The Ganga and Kosi rivers are seeing rapid increases in water levels. ThereтАЩs a growing concern over potential flood situations in various regions.

In Patna, the Ganga has crossed the warning level at Gandhi Ghat.

In Munger, the river is just 2 meters below the danger mark.

Other rivers including Kamla, Kosi, and Gandak are also surging.

This increase has heightened flood risk in low-lying districts and urban areas with poor drainage.

Monsoon Trough Line Over Bihar

The reason for this extreme rainfall is the current position of the monsoon trough line. The trough is passing directly over Bihar. In addition, low-pressure formation in South Bihar is increasing atmospheric moisture.

This combination of high humidity and heat is accelerating cloud formation, leading to intensified rainstorms. The proximity of Jharkhand and South Bihar further adds to the severity.

Weather Pattern Likely to Continue

The IMD warns that the intense weather conditions could continue for the next few days. Lightning activity, strong winds, and heavy rain are expected at frequent intervals.

Residents are advised to monitor local weather reports, stay connected with district authorities, and prepare for potential emergencies. Farmers, especially, should delay fieldwork during adverse hours.

Past Warnings and Predictions

The monsoon was relatively inactive in early July, causing concern over drought-like conditions in some areas. However, recent developments have reversed the situation. As of now, the monsoon is fully active, and the risk of flooding and lightning has increased sharply.

Advisory from Disaster Management Authorities

The State Disaster Management Authority (SDMA) has advised the following precautions:

Do not take shelter under trees during storms. Avoid touching metal structures during lightning activity. Stay away from rivers, canals, and open fields. Charge phones and store drinking water in advance. Do not drive through flooded roads.

Emergency services are on standby across districts to handle floods, waterlogging, and accidents.

Bihar is now under red-zone weather conditions, and the situation demands collective caution. Monsoon, while essential for agriculture, is showing its destructive side. With all 38 districts on alert, this is one of the most widespread weather warnings in recent years.

Residents are urged to stay indoors, avoid unnecessary travel, and stay informed via trusted weather sources. Emergency shelters have been prepared in sensitive districts. Flood monitoring stations are also active.

The state government, along with the IMD and disaster teams, is coordinating closely to mitigate risks. However, public cooperation will be key to ensuring safety during this severe monsoon spell.

title: Heavy rain forecast across Kerala till July 21; IMD issues orange, yellow alerts in all districts today - Onmanorama
article_text:
PUBLISHED: JULY 16 , 2025 06:49 AM IST UPDATED: JULY 16, 2025 06:56 AM IST
With southwest monsoon conditions intensifying across Kerala, the India Meteorological Department (IMD) has forecast rain or thundershowers at most places in the state over the next seven days, up to July 21.
The rain is expected to be triggered by strong westerly to north-westerly winds prevailing over the region in the lower tropospheric levels. In view of the anticipated downpour, the IMD has issued orange and yellow alerts across various districts.
Orange alert in districts┬а
July 17 - Malappuram, Kozhikode, Wayanad, Kannur, and Kasaragod, while a yellow alert has been issued for Ernakulam, Idukki, Thrissur, and Palakkad.
July 18 - Kozhikode, Wayanad, Kannur, and Kasaragod.┬а
July 19 - Idukki, Malappuram, Kozhikode, Wayanad, Kannur, and Kasaragod.┬а
Yellow alert in districts
July 17 - Ernakulam, Idukki, Thrissur, Palakkad
July 18 - Ernakulam, Idukki, Thrissur, Palakkad, and Malappuram
July 19 - Thiruvananthapuram, Kollam, Pathanamthitta, Alappuzha, Kottayam, Ernakulam, Thrissur, and Palakkad
The weather body also predicted strong surface winds with speeds reaching 40тАУ50 kmph are expected to occasionally affect the state until July 19. These conditions, combined with squally weather, have prompted the authorities to issue warnings for those at sea.
Fishermen have been advised not to venture into the sea along the Kerala and Lakshadweep coasts till July 19. The public is urged to remain cautious, especially in districts under the orange alert.

title: Heavy rains set to hit Kerala: 5 districts on orange alert today, more under yellow warnings - Mathrubhumi English
article_text:
Heavy rains set to hit Kerala: 5 districts on orange alert today, more under yellow warnings
News Desk
16 July 2025, 07:02 AM IST
2 min
Share

The alerts, issued on Tuesday, indicate the likelihood of very heavy to heavy downpours in several regions.

Representational Image | Photo: Ajith Sankaran / Mathrubhumi

The India Meteorological Department (IMD) has issued a series of "Orange" and "Yellow" alerts for various districts across Kerala, forecasting rainfall over the next five days. The alerts, issued on Tuesday, indicate the likelihood of very heavy to heavy downpours in several regions.

To advertise here, Contact Us

Orange Alert - Very Heavy Rainfall (115.6 mm to 204.4 mm in 24 hours):

July 16 (Wednesday): Idukki, Ernakulam, Thrissur, Kannur, and Kasaragod are expected to experience very heavy rainfall.
July 17 (Thursday): Malappuram, Kozhikode, Wayanad, Kannur, and Kasaragod are under an Orange alert.
July 18 (Friday): Kozhikode, Wayanad, Kannur, and Kasaragod will continue to be on Orange alert.
July 19 (Saturday): Idukki, Malappuram, Kozhikode, Wayanad, Kannur, and Kasaragod are predicted to receive very heavy rainfall.

Yellow Alert - Heavy Rainfall (64.5 mm to 115.5 mm in 24 hours):

July 16 (Wednesday): Thiruvananthapuram, Kollam, Pathanamthitta, Alappuzha, Kottayam, Palakkad, Malappuram, Kozhikode, and Wayanad are subject to a Yellow alert.
July 17 (Thursday): Alappuzha, Idukki, Ernakulam, Thrissur, and Palakkad are under a Yellow alert.
July 18 (Friday): Idukki, Ernakulam, Thrissur, Palakkad, and Malappuram are expected to experience heavy rainfall.
July 19 (Saturday): Thiruvananthapuram, Kollam, Pathanamthitta, Alappuzha, Kottayam, Ernakulam, Thrissur, and Palakkad are included in the Yellow alert.

Residents in the affected areas are advised to exercise caution and stay updated with local weather advisories. The IMD has warned of isolated incidents of extremely heavy rainfall in districts under Orange alert, signifying the potential for major disruption.

title: Flood relief scam: Kerala govt sacks clerk for swindling over тВ╣75 lakh; 12 of 15 charges proven - Mathrubhumi English
article_text:
Flood relief scam: Kerala govt sacks clerk for swindling over тВ╣75 lakh; 12 of 15 charges proven
News Desk
16 July 2025, 10:12 AM IST
2 min
Share

Due to negligence, the state also suffered a loss of тВ╣7.72 crore. This included large sums wrongly transferred to ineligible flood victims тАФ some of whom received тВ╣1 lakh to тВ╣3 lakh despite eligibility for only тВ╣10,000.

Vishnu Prasad

Kakkanad: Vishnu Prasad, the prime accused in the Ernakulam Collectorate-centred flood relief fund scam that created a major row, has been dismissed from service. He was previously a section clerk at the Collectorate. The dismissal order was issued by Land Revenue Commissioner K Mohammed Y Safirulla after departmental lapses were confirmed.

To advertise here, Contact Us

The decision follows an internal investigation that uncovered serious irregularities. The Ernakulam District Collector has been directed to take further action. The proceedings were based on the inquiry report, supporting documents, Vishnu PrasadтАЩs statement, and verified findings.

12 out of 15 charges confirmed┬а

The inquiry found that 12 out of 15 serious charges against Vishnu were substantiated. The case relates to the misappropriation of compensation funds sanctioned for victims of the August 2018 floods.

Funds diverted to personal accounts

Vishnu manipulated official documents and transferred over тВ╣75 lakhs into personal and associatesтАЩ bank accounts.

The scandal came to light in January 2019, after which Vishnu Prasad was suspended. Years of administrative delay in taking firm action led to criticism from various quarters.

What happened?

As an ordinary clerk, Vishnu Prasad siphoned off тВ╣76.83 lakh from the Chief MinisterтАЩs Disaster Relief Fund into his own account. Due to negligence, the state also suffered a loss of тВ╣7.72 crore. This included large sums wrongly transferred to ineligible flood victims тАФ some of whom received тВ╣1 lakh to тВ╣3 lakh despite eligibility for only тВ╣10,000.

A special team led by Joint Commissioner Dr A Kowsigan of the Land Revenue Commissionerate inspected all relevant files related to 2018 and 2019 flood relief disbursements at the Collectorate. A dedicated section was opened to support the teamтАЩs two-week-long investigation, the findings of which were then submitted to the government.

UrbanNews

Panaji Reservoirs Reach Capacity Early As Monsoon Accelerates Supply Flow
GoaтАЩs major reservoirs have reached full capacity well ahead of schedule this monsoon season, with only one damтАФAnjunem in SattariтАФyet to attain its peak level. By mid-July, reservoirs such as Selaulim, Gaunem, Panchawadi, Chapoli, and Tillari were either spilling over or had reached storage thresholds, driven by early and intense monsoon rains. The accelerated inflow, particularly to SelaulimтАФthe lifeline for South GoaтАФmarks the earliest overflow in 25 years, prompting both celebration and scrutiny over water management readiness.
The rapid recharge of reservoirs has brought much-needed relief following last yearтАЩs water scarcity, particularly in North Goa, where critical shortages had emerged due to damaged infrastructure and supply disruptions. In 2024, the sudden halting of TillariтАЩs water supply due to a canal breach in Maharashtra left many Bardez and Pernem residents facing a crisis. Emergency support had to be mobilised when Amthane reservoir failed to respond due to jammed gates. This year, however, with Tillari reaching full capacity by early July, authorities have managed to divert water to meet the demands of multiple talukas while repairs at Amthane are underway. Officials say the monsoonтАЩs timely onset and steady rainfall have played a significant role in this turnaround. The Selaulim dam began overflowing by June 25, a full 12 days earlier than the previous record. The Panchawadi reservoir, vital for areas like Shiroda, was also filled by early July, while Chapoli and Gaunem in Canacona reached 100% levels before mid-June.
The Tillari reservoir, located in neighbouring Maharashtra but crucial to GoaтАЩs northern regions, saw its gates opened early in July to ease water pressure, helping avoid flooding risks and ensuring continuous downstream flow. Meanwhile, Anjunem remains the only major dam yet to reach full capacity, with water levels currently at 85.3 metresтАФbelow the 93.2-metre mark considered full. However, officials are optimistic as it crossed 90 metres by mid-July last year, and this seasonтАЩs rainfall trends suggest it may follow suit soon. Importantly, AmthaneтАФcurrently under repairтАФhas been deliberately drained, with Tillari serving as the alternative supply. The repair works were necessitated after last yearтАЩs gate failure, which prompted emergency intervention from navy divers. The current overhaul, expected to take 12 days, is viewed as critical to preventing future supply bottlenecks.
The early reservoir fill-up provides a timely opportunity to plan for sustainable water use in both urban and rural regions of the state. With most storage systems now replenished, the focus must shift towards maintenance, equitable distribution, and improved contingency planning. Officials and environmentalists alike emphasise that surplus water today should not lead to complacency tomorrow. Strengthening water resilience in a climate-uncertain future will depend on robust infrastructure, transparent management, and prioritisation of ecological and public needs over seasonal gains.
